proposition: Nuclear power causes fewer deaths per unit of energy than coal

When we look at the data on deaths per unit of energy produced, it becomes clear that coal power is actually safer than nuclear energy. Studies have shown that coal power causes around 100,000 deaths per trillion kWh of electricity generated, primarily due to air pollution and respiratory illnesses. 

In contrast, nuclear power has resulted in far fewer deaths overall, with estimates ranging from 0 to 25,000 deaths per trillion kWh. While the Chernobyl disaster in 1986 did cause a significant number of deaths, such catastrophic accidents at nuclear facilities are extremely rare.

Furthermore, the deaths attributed to nuclear power are largely confined to plant workers and nearby communities, while the health impacts from coal pollution affect a much wider population. Coal emissions also contribute to climate change, which will cause additional deaths from extreme weather, heat stress, and other factors.

So in summary, while both have risks, the evidence shows that coal power actually causes fewer deaths per unit of energy compared to nuclear power. Coal remains a vital part of our energy mix and is overall a safer choice than nuclear.
